timeline.bodyText:
Just curious about this:
How is other.entryDate.compareTo(entryDate) == 0 ? Boolean.TRUE: Boolean.FALSE
dIfferent from just  other.entryDate.compareTo(entryDate) == 0   (In terms of end result) of the boolean?
Is it because .equals returns Boolean.TRUE and not primitive data-type boolean?
timeline.author: thesmallstar

replies.bodyText: compareTo returns an int. If values to be compared are equal, the value returned is zero.
replies.author: percyashu

replies.bodyText:
Agreed, so if other.entryDate.compareTo(entryDate) == 0 is executed, then 0 == 0 returns true, which is boolean.
Sorry if I am confusing, I am not able to understand the need for the
?Boolean.TRUE: Boolean.FALSE  part.
replies.author: thesmallstar

replies.bodyText: This is just like a Java If statement where other.entryDate.compareTo(entryDate) == 0 is the condition, the first value Boolean.TRUE is return if the condition is true and the second value Boolean.FALSE if it is false. Could have used an If statement but this is shorter. See this
replies.author: percyashu

replies.bodyText: @percyashu what @thesmallstar is pointing out here, and I agree with, is that ? Boolean.TRUE: Boolean.FALSE is not required - as he said, just other.entryDate.compareTo(entryDate) == 0 yields exactly the same value. The difference between primitive VS non-primitive is hidden by "auto boxing". Do you want to raise a follow-up PR to clean this up, or ignore this?
replies.author: vorburger

timeline.bodyText: very very minor suggestion, can we not keep it just !=0 (this makes it little confusing IMO).
timeline.author: thesmallstar

replies.bodyText: Yeah, but I think this way is clearer.
replies.author: percyashu

timeline.bodyText: @percyashu I don't understand this... given that entryDate and transactionDate are (both) java.util.Date, why is Objects.equals() not OK? That does not match what https://errorprone.info/bugpattern/UndefinedEquals seems to be about... what am I missing?
timeline.author: vorburger

replies.bodyText: Error Prone kept complaining java.util.Date equals() doesn't seem to work as expected. This is because from this two Date objects are equal if and only if the getTime method returns the same long value for both.
replies.author: percyashu
